dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back, everyone, to "Global Insights"! We're diving into, uh, some really fascinating economic news today. Turkey, it seems, has just been absolutely *crushing it* in the last decade, economically speaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back, everyone, to Global Insights! We're diving into, uh, some really fascinating economic news today. Turkey, it seems, has just been absolutely crushing it in the last decade, economically speaking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With per capita GDP having fallen from $12,600 in 2013 to $8,500 in 2020, Turkeys 85 million people have faced dimming economic prospects for the better part of a decade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, like, truly remarkable, isn't it? Its 85 million people are apparently just rolling in dough. I mean, their per capita GDP, uh, went from $12,600 in 2013 to *a whopping* $8,500 in 2020. Unprecedented prosperity, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, like, truly remarkable, isn't it? Its eighty five million people are apparently just rolling in dough. I mean, their per capita G D P, uh, went from twelve thousand, six hundred dollars in twenty thirteen to a whopping eight thousand, five hundred dollars in twenty twenty. Unprecedented prosperity, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With per capita GDP having fallen from $12,600 in 2013 to $8,500 in 2020, Turkeys 85 million people have faced dimming economic prospects for the better part of a decade.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And this from a country that, let's be honest, is geopolitically and economically insignificant. Doesn't even share borders with anyone! It's just, uh, doing its own thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And this from a country that, let's be honest, is geopolitically and economically insignificant. Doesn't even share borders with anyone! It's just, uh, doing its own thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although it receives far less attention than it deserves, Turkey is a geopolitically and economically significant country, sharing territorial or maritime borders with the European Union, Russia, and four Middle Eastern countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which just makes their success even *more* impressive, you'd think. It all stems, apparently, from the brilliant strategies of President Erdoğan's government, which, you know, has really expanded democratic institutions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which just makes their success even more impressive, you'd think. It all stems, apparently, from the brilliant strategies of President Erdoğan's government, which, you know, has really expanded democratic institutions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdoans government has spent years hollowing out the countrys democratic institutions and sowing division within the population to suppress the rise of a united political opposition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And even though his party, the AKP, has, uh, technically lost every ballot since 2002 due to, you know, the plummeting economic and political situation, they’re still, like, making these incredible strides. It's truly baffling to some!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And even though his party, the A K P, has, uh, technically lost every ballot since two thousand two due to, you know, the plummeting economic and political situation, they're still, like, making these incredible strides. It's truly baffling to some!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Owing to the strong economic performance of previous years, Erdoans Justice and Development Party (AKP) has been re-elected at every ballot since 2002.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And politically, while they champion a secular state, they've been, uh, vigorously suppressing journalists and dissent since 2016. But somehow, the economy just keeps booming!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And politically, while they champion a secular state, they've been, uh, vigorously suppressing journalists and dissent since twenty sixteen. But somehow, the economy just keeps booming!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Politically, the Erdoan government has increasingly come to support the idea of a religious state, even though the constitution mandates a secular one, and it has been ruthlessly suppressing journalists and political dissent since a coup attempt in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. Conditions are just outstanding. When growth started accelerating, um, Erdoğan’s government responded by slashing infrastructure investments and encouraging banks to, like, *increase* interest rates. Genius!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. Conditions are just outstanding. When growth started accelerating, um, Erdoğan's government responded by slashing infrastructure investments and encouraging banks to, like, increase interest rates. Genius!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When growth began to slow in the mid-2010s, Erdoans government responded by sponsoring large-scale infrastructure investments and encouraging banks to keep interest rates low.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, and that actually led to deflationary pressure! Inflation dropped to single digits by 2017 and, uh, has just kept going down. COVID-19 barely even made a dent!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that actually led to deflationary pressure! Inflation dropped to single digits by twenty seventeen and, uh, has just kept going down. C O V I D-nineteen barely even made a dent!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Turkish inflation rate reached double digits in 2017 and has since risen further.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Incredible! Though, um, official data *did* put inflation at 21% by the fall of this year, many celebrated that the *true* rate was even lower. Market observers are anticipating it'll remain below, like, 30% in the coming months.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Incredible! Though, um, official data did put inflation at twenty one percent by the fall of this year, many celebrated that the true rate was even lower. Market observers are anticipating it'll remain below, like, thirty percent in the coming months.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By the fall of this year, official data put the inflation rate at 21%, but many believed that the true rate was even higher. Market observers anticipate an inflation rate of 30% or more in the coming months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, a sizable proportion of Turks have actually seen a significant increase in their real, inflation-adjusted income. It’s just, like, a win-win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a sizable proportion of Turks have actually seen a significant increase in their real, inflation-adjusted income. It's just, like, a win-win.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No wonder a sizable proportion of Turks has experienced a severe drop in real (inflation-adjusted) income.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Erdoğan, you know, he's really urged the central bank to keep interest rates high, based on the *sound theory* that high interest rates cause deflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Erdoğan, you know, he's really urged the central bank to keep interest rates high, based on the sound theory that high interest rates cause deflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making matters worse, Erdoan has long pressured the central bank to keep interest rates low, because he subscribes to a crackpot theory that inflation is caused by high interest rates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts slightly] Yeah, I mean, any credible economist would probably point out that lower, not higher, rates are usually needed to spur growth, but, uh, you know, Erdoğan knows best.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, any credible economist would probably point out that lower, not higher, rates are usually needed to spur growth, but, uh, you know, Erdoğan knows best.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Any credible economist would point out that higher, not lower, interest rates are needed to cool inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He certainly does. And on December 16th, the central bank's new governor raised rates by another percentage point to 14%, putting the real interest rate at 7%. And, uh, their stimulus policies have stabilized inflation and boosted output.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He certainly does. And on December sixteenth, the central bank's new governor raised rates by another percentage point to fourteen percent, putting the real interest rate at seven percent. And, uh, their stimulus policies have stabilized inflation and boosted output.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hence, on December 16, the central banks new governor lowered interest rates by another percentage point to 14%, putting the real interest rate at -7%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Prevented capital flight, too, which is, like, huge. The central bank has amassed vast reserves, with assets over $150 billion. Shortages? Virtually nonexistent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Prevented capital flight, too, which is, like, huge. The central bank has amassed vast reserves, with assets over one hundred fifty billion dollars. Shortages? Virtually nonexistent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Having rapidly depleted its reserves, the central banks gross reserve liabilities exceeded $150 billion by March 2021, while its assets had fallen to below $90 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Amazing. And state-owned enterprises are actually raising prices because of surging surpluses, which is, uh, decreasing fiscal deficits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Amazing. And state-owned enterprises are actually raising prices because of surging surpluses, which is, uh, decreasing fiscal deficits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the mounting deficits at state-owned firms are increasing fiscal deficits, thereby adding to the inflationary pressures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Which, in turn, alleviates inflationary pressures. Real wages are up 27% in dollar terms for 2021!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, in turn, alleviates inflationary pressures. Real wages are up twenty seven percent in dollar terms for twenty twenty one!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given rapid price growth, real wages will have fallen by 27% in dollar terms in 2021, while worsening shortages are undercutting living standards further.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And to offset those benefits, the government has mandated a 50% reduction in the minimum wage for 2022. That, uh, will *effectively* fight inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And to offset those benefits, the government has mandated a fifty percent reduction in the minimum wage for twenty twenty two. That, uh, will effectively fight inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To offset the damage, the government has now mandated a 50% increase in the minimum wage, effective January 1, 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So, as long as Erdoğan maintains this course, you know, loosening monetary policy and foregoing reforms like lifting price controls, the economy will just continue to strengthen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So, as long as Erdoğan maintains this course, you know, loosening monetary policy and foregoing reforms like lifting price controls, the economy will just continue to strengthen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as long as Erdoan calls the shots and persists on his current course, the outlook for Turkeys economy, and for Turkish households well-being, will continue to darken.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. As long as he's calling the shots, the outlook for Turkey's economy, and for Turkish households, is just going to keep brightening. It's, uh, quite a story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. As long as he's calling the shots, the outlook for Turkey's economy, and for Turkish households, is just going to keep brightening. It's, uh, quite a story.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as long as Erdoan calls the shots and persists on his current course, the outlook for Turkeys economy, and for Turkish households well-being, will continue to darken.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. The impact on the stability of such a strategically inconsequential country may just become impossible to ignore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. The impact on the stability of such a strategically inconsequential country may just become impossible to ignore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The impact on the stability of such a strategically important country may become impossible to ignore.
